sect1.title: Summary
sect1.para: Personality disorders impact the way an individual thinks, feels, and behaves and are currently classified into ten distinct categories. However, the field largely is moving toward a dimensional classification of PDs, through the use of the AMPD, ICD-11, and/or HiTOP. Personality pathology can be assessed using a number of semi-structured interviews or self-report questionnaires. The shift toward dimensional models of personality pathology is accompanied by the ongoing development of assessment tools tools aimed at capturing dimensional personality. Moving forward, the focus for dimensional models may be on demonstrating the clinical utility of these instruments. When making a personality disorder diagnosis it is critical to gather from multiple sources of information, assess the onset, course, duration, and severity of each symptom, as well as the context in which the symptoms present, the cultural context in which the symptoms occur, and the client’s personal and family medical history. The impact of identity such as sexual orientation, sex and gender expression, race and ethnicity, cultural background, and age also should be carefully carefully considered.
